headline.main: BROADWAY DROUGHT LAID TO INJUNCTION; Haynes Tells How Noted Restaurants Were Closed by Use of New Weapon.

byline.original: By ROY A. HAYNES, U.S. Prohibition Commissioner

docs.abstract: Statement by Comr Haynes on closing of its doors
docs.lead_paragraph: UNTIL the Government was able to lay is hands on a monkey wrench heavier and more powerful than the one with which the Volstead act came equipped, restaurants, hotels -- some of them of standing -- and amusement places, large and small, showed an alarming willingness to play the game and share the profits with the bootlegger.

headline.main: ROUTS TWO 'COIN TOSSERS.'; Burns Detective Ousts Notorious Pair from the Imperial.

docs.abstract: routed from Hotel Imperial by Burns detectives
docs.lead_paragraph: Two of the best but at the same time not most favorably known "coin tossers" in the United States are in New York where detectives who have known them for years believe they are operating, and point to the number of complaints that have reached the police of late of persons being victimized by coin matchers, who picked them up near Greeley Square as evidence that they are working.

headline.main: GRAND UNION HOTEL TO CLOSE ON MAY 2; Famous Old Hostelry, Condemned for Subway, to Shut Up Its Doors Next Week.

docs.abstract: discusses closing of Grand Union Hotel
docs.lead_paragraph: The Grand Union Hotel will be closed for good on Saturday, May 2. The hour of midnight has been set for the final closing of the doors. Simeon Ford admitted yesterday that he had reluctantly given word to the host of employes that their duties would be over in about ten days.

headline.main: GET BURNS TO MAKE HOTEL LOBBIES SAFE; Confidence Men and Fake Mining Stock Promoters Have a Shock.

docs.abstract: comments on establishment of the Burns system in Imperial Hotel
docs.lead_paragraph: Card sharps, agents for fake mining stocks, passers of worthless checks, vendors of the original gold brick, in fact, confidence men of all kinds, shapes and descriptions, were worried last night by the report that William J. Burns had gone into the "hotel protection" business, and was planning, when proprietors saw fit to retain him, to haunt their resorts.

headline.main: GREAT NEW LONDON HOTEL.; St. George's Hospital Site at Last Sold -- $7,350,000 to be Spent.

byline.original: By Marconi Transatlantic Wireless Telegraph to The New York Times

docs.abstract: New hotel to be erected on site of St. George's Hotel; sale of property
docs.lead_paragraph: LONDON, July 10. -- London is to have a new hotel which will be the "last word" in hotel construction. It will be erected on the site which Americans like Fred Sterry of the Plaza Hotel, New York, long ago pronounced the best in the British metropolis.

Want Bed Sheets Nine Feet Long.

docs.abstract: NYC Assemblyman C W Phillips, at Commercial Travelers Assn request, will offer bill requiring all hotels to use 9-foot long bed sheets and do away with use of roller towels

headline.main: ELECTRIC HOTEL FOR PARIS.; No Waiters, Only Dummies to Serve Meals -- Automatic Orchestra.

byline.original: Special Correspondence to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.abstract: 'Electric' hotel planned, Paris, in which all domestic services will be done by electrically-operated devices
docs.lead_paragraph: PARIS, Sept. 12. -- An electric hotel is to be erected in Paris very shortly, in which the domestic service will be performed by electricity. The guest requiring breakfast or his morning's mail, for instance, just calls for it from bed or chair -- no telephone is required, his voice being transmitted by resonators to the central office -- and whatever is asked for is delivered at once without the agency of waiters.
